title: Thermodynamics specific heat and ideal gas law

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.A group of students are asked to design a lab to identify an unknown metal by determining the metal’s specific heat from a graph. They have access to a beaker, a hot plate, a thermometer, and a scale. The beaker can be insulated. The specific heat <math alttext="c sub w" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>c</mi><mi>w</mi></msub></math> of water is known.(a) Design an experimental procedure that the students could use to collect the data needed to determine the specific heat of the unknown metal. Provide enough detail so another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

They have access to a beaker, a hot plate, a thermometer, and a scale. The beaker can be insulated. The specific heat <math alttext="c sub w" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>c</mi><mi>w</mi></msub></math> of water is known.(a) Design an experimental procedure that the students could use to collect the data needed to determine the specific heat of the unknown metal. Provide enough detail so another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.
(b) Describe how the students could analyze the collected data to determine the specific heat of the unknown metal.

In a second experiment, the students have an uninsulated cylinder of gas that is sealed by a moveable piston. There is a pressure sensor inside the cylinder and friction between the piston and the cylinder is negligible. The students place the cylinder of gas in a water bath that is held at a constant temperature of <math alttext="293 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mn>293</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></math>. They add objects of various mass to the top of the cylinder to slowly compress the gas. The students record the pressure <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mi>P</mi></math> and the volume <math alttext="V" overflow="scroll"><mi>V</mi></math> of the gas. Indicate what measured and/or calculated quantities could be graphed to yield a straight line that could be used to calculate the number of moles of gas in the cylinder. Use the blank columns in the table to list any calculated quantities you will graph other than the data provided. Horizontal Axis:__________ Vertical Axis:__________
ii. Plot the data points for the quantities indicated in part (c)(i) on the graph provided. Clearly scale and label all axes, including units. Draw a straight line that best represents the data.
(d) Using the best-fit line calculate the number of moles of gas in the cylinder.
